Amstel Malta: The Low-Sugar Malt Amstel Malta: The Low-Sugar Malt

Amstel Malta, a new brand of Malt drink low in sugar con- tent, has been introduced into the Nigerian market. Amstel Malta, a new brand of Malt drink low in sugar con- tent, has been introduced into the Nigerian market.

Since consumers have been com- plaining of high levelsugar content in different types of malt drinks which they claim is unhealthy, Ni- gerian Breweries Limited decided to introduce Amstel Malta. Since consumers have been com- plaining of high levelsugar content in different types of malt drinks which they claim is unhealthy, Ni- gerian Breweries Limited decided to introduce Amstel Malta.

The marketing manager, NBL, Mr. Bola Akingbade, presenting Amstel Malta last week Thursday in Lagos said that "the low sugar product profile of Amstel Malta is an extra value-added benefit which The marketing manager, NBL, Mr. Bola Akingbade, presenting Amstel Malta last week Thursday in Lagos said that "the low sugar product profile of Amstel Malta is an extra value-added benefit which

Mr. Akingbade said that, "most Nigerians who are not regular con- sumers of malt drinks because of the worrying effects of their per- ceived highersugar level and their fat-inducing implications now have the opportunity of enjoying the fantastic taste of Amstel Malta without the worries of over-weight related problems." Mr. Akingbade stressed that the development of Amstel Malta by NBL is a practical demonstration of the firm's faith in the Nigerian economy in spite of the economic depression. Pa Ibitola Pa Ibitola

The death has been announced of Pa Reuben Oyebode Ibitola, a high chief of Usi-Ekit in Ondo state. Pa Ibitola, a retired produce buyer and big time farmer, died in his residence at B5 Anaye Street, Usi-Ekiti on 21 Novem- ber at the ripe age of87. He was burled 22 November. Pa Ibitola is survived by many children among whom is Mr. Femi Ibitola of Michelin. The death has been announced of Pa Reuben Oyebode Ibitola, a high chief of Usi-Ekit in Ondo state. Pa Ibitola, a retired produce buyer and big time farmer, died in his residence at B5 Anaye Street, Usi-Ekiti on 21 Novem- ber at the ripe age of87. He was burled 22 November. Pa Ibitola is survived by many children among whom is Mr. Femi Ibitola of Michelin.

You can hardly miss them. From about 50 meters away their aroma assail your nose, igniting a hunger you did not know existed. As you move closer you are arrested by the array of various delicacies - plan- tain, yam, akara, potatoes, puff-puff, fish, all fried and all looking allur- ingly, mouth-wateringly appetizing. You can hardly miss them. From about 50 meters away their aroma assail your nose, igniting a hunger you did not know existed. As you move closer you are arrested by the array of various delicacies - plan- tain, yam, akara, potatoes, puff-puff, fish, all fried and all looking allur- ingly, mouth-wateringly appetizing.

You move nearer and suddenly remember that you are in the midst of a throng of people at a major bus stop. Afraid a friend will see you, you pause, then turn round to go on your way. But you find the aroma irresistible, shrug your shoulders, move nearer the tray of akara, pick a piece and throw It into your mouth all in one movement. WUNMI RABIU WUNMI RABIU

A man sits frying while two young ; girls just entering womanhood attend to customers who stream in endlessly. It strikes your suddenly, that this is another popular joint for Lagosians in a hurry. A man sits frying while two young ; girls just entering womanhood attend to customers who stream in endlessly. It strikes your suddenly, that this is another popular joint for Lagosians in a hurry.

Indeed at many bus-stops, these mobile kitchens cater for the usually busy Lagosians who have little time to settle down fora real meal. The buyers whose faces reveal unmistakable we- are-in-a-hurry look quickly stop, get what they want and do justice to it as they move on. Indeed at many bus-stops, these mobile kitchens cater for the usually busy Lagosians who have little time to settle down fora real meal. The buyers whose faces reveal unmistakable we- are-in-a-hurry look quickly stop, get what they want and do justice to it as they move on.

At Oshodi, a nice looking young man stopped to get some plantain and potatoes. One expects such a man to settle for meat pie or things of that stuff. According to him, he would rather go for the fried food because it is economical. "Meatple doesn't come cheap these days, so I think this will do since I don't have time to eat a real meal until I get home in the night," he explained. At Oshodi, a nice looking young man stopped to get some plantain and potatoes. One expects such a man to settle for meat pie or things of that stuff. According to him, he would rather go for the fried food because it is economical. "Meatple doesn't come cheap these days, so I think this will do since I don't have time to eat a real meal until I get home in the night," he explained.

Olabiyi, a bachelor patronises the mobile kitchen because he does not have time to cook at home. "I am a busy man so I mainly eat outside and most times I eat all these fried food." For Bisola, a trader, eating fried foods has become an obsession. "De- spite the fact that I eat at home before coming to the shop in the morning and I even bring my lunch in a flask, I still find it difficult to resist the urge to buy from these people," she said. Olabiyi, a bachelor patronises the mobile kitchen because he does not have time to cook at home. "I am a busy man so I mainly eat outside and most times I eat all these fried food." For Bisola, a trader, eating fried foods has become an obsession. "De- spite the fact that I eat at home before coming to the shop in the morning and I even bring my lunch in a flask, I still find it difficult to resist the urge to buy from these people," she said.
Some other people, however, prefer buying fried food from the Some other people, however, prefer buying fried food from the

roadside because it not only saves time, it saves them the expenses of cooking at home. Ola for instance said though he likes fried plantain, he can- notafford the high prices of plantain in Lagos. So he prefers getting some from the road side without stress. A woman who also spoke in line with this said: "I enjoy cooking a lot but frying gives me a lot of problems. I often get my food burnt so I prefer to buy fried food. Besides, I can hardly think of yam or puff-puff at home so whenever I feel like taking them I visit the roadside." roadside because it not only saves time, it saves them the expenses of cooking at home. Ola for instance said though he likes fried plantain, he can- notafford the high prices of plantain in Lagos. So he prefers getting some from the road side without stress. A woman who also spoke in line with this said: "I enjoy cooking a lot but frying gives me a lot of problems. I often get my food burnt so I prefer to buy fried food. Besides, I can hardly think of yam or puff-puff at home so whenever I feel like taking them I visit the roadside."

PM News spoke to a few of the men who run the mobile kitchen. "It provides fast food for those who can hardly sit down to eat due to the nature of their jobs," said Sunday. According to him some people are so tired by the time they close at the office that there is no way they can get home and start cooking. "They rather settle for these for convenience" he added.
